content:
er 17, 2015
												3/10With all the hype I heard from this game I expected an enjoyable experience involving me controlling my minions, tormenting local villagers and their livestock, and being the badass I suspected I would be. No. That exists, but the game is so much worse than that.The mechanics work when they want to, the collision detection is either there or not, the combat leaves a lot to be desired, and the writing and voice acting is EXTREMELY poor. After spending hours roaming the forest, lost, and then later the dwarven hills, lost, it was apparent that this game needs a mini map in the most DESPERATE way. Even a normal map would have been fine just so I could know where the ♥♥♥♥ to go! Controlling my minions was enjoyable until I had 30+. Then it became an annoyance of trying to get all of them to cooperate together to get from point A to point B. They also like to drown in water. That’s fine I get it. However when the water is ankle deep and the minions are knee high and they drown I’M CALLING ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T!The combat is extremely bland, Most of the time you send your minions out to fight and only need 10 at most to destroy the living hell out of everything, but there comes a time where you just gotta get your hands dirty. ♥♥♥♥ THAT! The amount of times I had 5+ enemies surround me and I swing my weapon thinking, "I'll get a hit on all of them and take them out in no time." WRONG! You get surrounded be prepared to take some more damage than you thought. Each hit focuses on one enemy at a time. ONE? I'M NOT POKING THEM INDIVIDUALLY! MY SWORD/AXE/WHAT EVER I FEEL LIKE USING WILL HIT ALL OF THEM! NOT JUST ONE!I thought that maybe the forging system could help this in that I could get some bonuses and become even MORE of a badass. Wrong again. To upgrade and forger items you have to infuse them with the souls of your minions. And only certain creatures have souls to drop which doesn’t make sense since every enemy should drop some soul! So because I only get a limited amount of souls from creatures that destroy my minions easily you end up having to grind your face on a wall for an hour only to get 400+ souls. 400 is a pretty big number, however when crafting you can infuse up to 2000 souls. 2000?! This is for only 1 item. NOT EVEN AN UPGRADED ITEM! A BASE ITEM! SO I THEN HAVE TO SPEND MORE SOULS TO UPGRADE MY WEAPON! 3000 SOULS! I’m sorry, but having me use my 50,000+ gold would have been enough.Which brings me to the money system. You get money which you use to upgrade your tower and to spend on the crafting items. After spending all the money I could to upgrade my tower I ran out of useful things to spend it on and accumulated 50,000+ by the end of the game. I don’t see how they could have run out of things to use money on. Every time you summon a fresh minion it will either have armor it gathered from a previous mission or come out naked as the day it was born. Why not use the money to give any minions better armor? Better weapons? No you upgrade that by choosing a specific wench to join you in the tower. Wow. One upgrade. Don’t want to make you too overpowered in a game where your minions literally get ♥♥♥♥ on around every corner."SPOILER ALERT"The story I thought was going to be pretty straight forward. Show dominance and you win when you become the OVERLORD! Not exactly. You go about finding minion nests, then take out some of the local annoyances and the come back to the tower to discover that you were just helping an evil wizard, aka the REAL Overlord, to sneak back into the tower and everyone to stab you in the back because ♥♥♥♥ you the other guy was here first a long time ago. You have one last puzzle with some loyal minions help and then fight said wizard in a fight that will be long forgotten by the time I read a text message.With all this I give the game a 3/10.A game with dodgy mechanics, unmemorable bosses, poor story and voice acting, maze like levels with NO maps, and systems that become redundant.

												Hear is my review for overlord it's got a lot of problems and one of the bad points I thought about this game is is there a repetitive areas spoiler alert you got a collect different colour minions and every area you go to collect different colour minions is a different area but you do the same thing killing the enemy then Killing the boss getting minions you gotta do that 4 times and it gets very very very boring and you do this for most of the game and in general it is boreing you run around basically doing the same thing and I found it got very frustrating and the quest descriptions not very clear and hard to find what you doing and you run around like a headless chicken but saying that the minions are very funny the intro is very funny the storyline is  just getting minions to become the overlord to upgrade the tower to control some villages and the game is extremely hard and some of the boss is a crazy too hard and Overall I would not recommend buying overlord one personally I think it's too frustrating and to confusing and boring but saying that the minions are funny.  And there's a crafting system that you can use to make armour and weapons but the problem is that you use Souls two upgrade you get for killing enemies ok but when you make two armour pieces for example and then you want put fire on one and say poison on the othet and it is hard to see what chest piece you have on so you have to go back and forward from your forge to your wardrobe and check to find out what one you have on it is a Absolute nightmare and if you want to give you chest piece a health boost so you have to collect like a round 600 souls i know not quite right number but you end running around the same over and over again to get the Souls.  And you use the Souls two summon you minions and so you have to go back and kill things like sheep to get more souls and all sorts of things over and over and over again to get those that you have to go back and do it again and again it is crazy how many things you have to do in this game over and over again

content:
18, 2016
												Just played through Overlord. Overall I'd probably give it a 5/10.Voice acting: Pretty terrible.Graphics: passablegameplay: quite fun, single redeeming featuremusic: forgettableYou are dug out of a crypt with no explanation of how you got there. It's time to be an evil overlord. Teleport around doing...stuff and building up armies of minions. The game was on sale for a few dollars so I figured I'd try it out.There were a lot of side features to this game that I didn't get into simply because I wanted to finish it. The plot hooks felt a little desperate and unnatural. I think a game in which the protagonist is evil requires a different kind of reason to go somewhere beyond "there's a plague there."There is a crafting system that requires you to sacrifice your minions to improve your equipment. However, the number of minions that I had to sacrifice to get some mediocre improvements actually backfired in the last level because I ran out of minions and had to grind/farm up some more.There's a few puzzles in this game, which frequently are a grind to get through. Combat is typically over very shortly when you overwhelm the opposition with your minions, or some new enemy wipes out large numbers of minions until you figure out how to beat it.I ran into a few annoying bugs, one that went in my favor and one that killed a lot of my minions.This game reminded me of Fable meets Pikmin. The whole game took me about 10 hours to beat, and for the last 4 of those I was getting antsy to see the end because I wasn't having much fun. Frankly I would have gotten more enjoyment from playing Pikmin again. The controls were a little clunky. Virtually every piece of dialogue was so tropey/cliched/badly voice-acted that it made me wince on a few occasions. This game wasn't bad, but felt like a chore to get through, and I beat it in 10 hours.

, 2015
												Overlord (my game includes the 'Raising hell' DLC) is essentially a Pathfinding game wrapped up in a cute graphics and a story of an Evil Overlord carving out his domain.It is good for what it does but the concept, the style and the game play soon run out of new tricks and after a couple of hours in it starts to be more of a grind than a pleasure.There are a few things that really annoy me but the biggest is the incessant Cut-Scenes.OK, i get it you are trying to tell me a story but why would you break up nearly every major fight with flow-stopping cut-scene? It gets really tedious and in the end i cared less about the story because of it... i just pressed <space> to fast-forward.I am still playing it and will play it through, it is less boring than watching TV and so it is a good little filler in-between other stuff but honestly, if i stopped playing it tomorrow and deleted i would not miss itOh, and the lawn-mowing mini-game is a steaming POS

content:
11, 2015
												This game deserves some credit; they wanted to use a controller, and give you the kind of control you are used to with a PC. And honestly, they do a decent job, because that's a hard task. When you first start this game, it seems like it's going to be some form of an RTS; you controlling The Overlord directly, but also directing his growing band of minions.  The Overlord uses magic and melee, while different kinds of minions attack physically, magically, stealthily, etc, and you control it all directly. Pretty cool.Well, it should be. Despite doing a surprisingly good job as I said above, there are still many problems. I've quit and reloaded several times (irritatingly limited save system) because my minions have all charged into fire or poison gas or a lake and died immediately because of a button press. My fault, yeah, I did it. But why should it even be possible to murder all your followers by ordering them into a river? Just make them stop at the water's edge so that if I accidentally, even one time, forget to change over to just the minions who walk on water, I don't lose the whole level and die. And this happens more than you would think, because this game is not a strategic combat game, it's an action/adventure game with puzzle elements. The minions are mostly there to get through puzzles that become increasingly irritating. Because the perspective is directly on the Overlord, it can be difficult to control the minions at a distance (in fact, you lose all control after a surprisingly short distance). They run into things, they aren't standing quite where you thought they were, they get lost. It's also kind of annoying to do things like seperate the minions, position them, recall them out of comabey they have been "locked" in to, etc. Really, the Overlord is actually a pain in the butt; he's a hindrance and a distraction, as he's not very tough or useful most of the time. If he was not there, or just there as a Wizard with a magic barrier who follows the minions around and you just control THEM, it would be far better, because you'd have more buttons to work with, instead of several just to control the very basic avatar. And the puzzles are not hard; it's one of those games where you know what to do immediately, but can't effectively do it. Constantly fighting with hit-and-run tactics, trying to navigate over terrain that's difficult to see (although you can change the camera angle, that robs you of the ability to see more than 20 feet away), it really just drags. The combat parts are the fun parts, and with some tweaking to the mechanics and different levels design, it would of been a fun and somewhat unique combat game. Instead it's an average action-adventure title combined with an easy puzzle game. It's not terrible, but it's frustrating, and straddles too many fences to offer any depth or satisfaction in any field. The first 2-3 hours were fun, then it starts to slow down, and by ten, I just threw down the controller in frustration, as I couldn't get through 30 minutes without something going royally wrong (including freezes, enemies cheaply spawning right behind you and killing your weakest guys in a flash, and the fact that you can't unsummon your minions when needed). Good effort, in a way, by the devs, but it's not enough to make the game really worth playing.

content:
7, 2015
												TL:DRIts boring and drags on incredibly long. Its a budget game so don't expect a whole lot either.I would say Overlord was like Pikmin, if I had ever played Pikmin I think.  Unfortunately like some other games where you command units while being a character yourself the actual gameplay that you do (you directly hacking and slashing) kinda sucks. There isn't a real fighting mechanic here, not even any rolls (the stuff popularized by Dark Souls) you just hammer the attack button or take a few steps back or use a magic spell.  This is really more of an RPG and a puzzle game than something about combat...or atleast thats what I think its supposed to be that. The puzzles thus far have required ridiculous amounts of back tracking at times and basically trying every path in the game till I find the one I need to go down or till I look up a guide. The announcer/narrator is basically useless most the time in helping you solve problems. He will make a statement that will make absolutely no sense and its impossible to tell if this is applicable to the issue at hand or if its just random lore that dousn't actually matter. Am I supposed to just brute force and kill an enemy or use the narrators information to beat it more easily, tough ♥♥♥♥ figuring it out when theres no items or items of context in the area.Controls are a pain, it can be hard to get minions to do what you want them to do and thats using a joystick/gamepad/controller. This can mean they stand there and let themselves get killed one by one or they end up running into a wall or getting stuck at a waters edge or to far from you. Its just a major pain in the ♥♥♥ managing them to the point between this and the pisspoor quests/backtracking and uninteresting combat that whatever good features this game has dousn't even seem to be worth it. It looks and sounds good enough, but gawd its a boring and uninteresting game and not a particularly good RPG either.Maybe I'll find a gem in the rough if I play later, but this is one budget title thats really padded out.

content:
, 2014
												Wonderful idea, decent cutesy graphics, hilarious voice work, sluggish controls, confusing mechanics, some nasty bugs and a main character who's movement speed is juuuust the wrong side of infuriatingly slow. If you're REALLY into it, or get lucky and don't encounter any problems, you'll probably love this game but I've entirely lost my patience... :(I'm writing this after my fourth attempt at the same level after three separate bugs forced me to restart. One crash, one glitch into terrain and one incidence of bad design left me stranded with no way to complete the level. There's no quick-saves, only progress-based autosaves, so if something goes wrong you'll have to replay large chunks of the game over again. Additionally the Metroidvania-ish level design forces you to do a lot of back-tracking.When it works it's a lot of fun. Pillaging hobbit holes, building my evil lair and watching my hordes grow and arm themselves was compelling for a few hours but, in the end, my frustration overcame my enjoyment.

number of helpful: 20 of 62 people (32%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
y 6, 2015
												Disclaimer: Inflated game time. Time needed to complete one playthrough: 16h (all content).A very long time ago I remember picking up Overlord for forty euro's on launch day at the local game store. How that seems to feel like ages past. I first played Overlord when I was very young, and when I played it I was immediately hooked. I still have the physical retail copy sitting in my closet, still filled with maps of every single dungeon that I myself drew, because I loved this game THAT much. Now that I finally replay it more than seven years later I have absolutely no idea why I loved this game, and that goes to show you that time doesn't wait for anybody. Overlord is a buggy game, as it has crashed multiple times on my system. Overlord has absolutely abysmal controls. Not because the concept of moving yourself around and controlling minions is difficult, but because the controls are unresponsive and clunky. Sometimes the controls simply would not work: I made the input and nothing happens, often leading to your plan being ruined and causing much frustration.Overlord is also a game of high promises made shallow and paper-thin. You control a poor man's Sauron through a parody of popular fantasy landscapes in search of a plot. You aren't doing this alone, as you have a small and unintimidating number of brain (and AI)-challenged minions who follow you around and "obey your every command". While I jokingly said that you were in search of a plot, I was only semi-serious. Your quest is to avenge your predecessor by slaying all seven Heroes who vanquished him, and, while you're at it, re-take over the world. All seven Heroes have become corrupt due to wealth and fame bestowed upon them for succeeding in the quest they undertook. Rhianna Pratchett of all people wrote this game, and while there are occasionally a few "Haha. That's funny. I guess."-moments in the game, most of it honestly feels very forced. It REALLY doesn't help that every single character looks the same, and looking at the lip-synching too long may make you go blind. Seriously, the lip-synching in this game is the stuff of belly-aching hilarity. Or just horror. When anybody talks, it looks as if the game is honestly glitched, of if the animator had a mouth-foaming seizure that day and the janitor had to fill in the blanks.Graphically the game still looks okay in my book. But be warned, people: 2007 was still in the age of overused bloom and plastic looking textures, though the developers DID try to avoid this in Overlord. The screenshots do a very good job at showing you the actual visuals of how the game is going to look on your screen, minus the UI, of course. The real problem with this game is that it's overly ambitious to make you feel like an Overlord, a true Dark Lord of Evil, but this promise rings just as hollow as any cave because the Overlord:-can be easily stunlocked in combat by slugs;-controls and fights like he has a broomstick up his an*s;-has an EVIL TOWER OF DOOOOOM that only has four "large" rooms to explore;-(said tower can also not hold more than one mistress for a reason that's never explained to us);-can at the very maximum carry 50 weak minions with him;-has to find the objects that ALLOW him to carry more minions with him, because he starts out with a maximum of five;-has four types of Minions to choose from, yet out of four, three of them can die almost instantly in combat;-has a Minion Master that apparantly runs every single decision for him, not making him as an Evil Genius but more of a a Silent Dumb Soldier.... but I guess "Silent Dumb Soldier" as the title of this game wouldn't have broken the bank in terms of sales numbers (as if there wasn't enough of that back in 2k7). All joking aside, I do hope you guys see my problem here. This is a game that just brings the bare minimum of what is promised and after playing it again it just isn't my idea of what a fantasy evil master would do. That's not to say that this game is worthless though, there IS hard work poured into it, but it's 'One of Those Games' where you have to make your own fun, because the game certainly won't make it for you. As always, only buy it when it's on sale. Hopefully Overlord III will make some of my evil ambitions come true.My specs:Windows 7 64-bitIntel Core i7 920 2.67GHz6GB RAMMSI 660Ti OC Power Edition

number of helpful: 3 of 24 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												Overlord has interesting game mechanics that enables you to command an army of his own to defeat enemies. The Overlord himself is quite weak while the character building is mainly focus on the minions the player command. This tests the your ability to strategize your minion types and how well you control them. It makes the game quite fun when you overcome a challenge that overwelms both you and your army. But I wouldn't recommand (or try to get it at discounted price) because of some major (imho) flaws.I am 8 hours into this game while writing this review. That is because this game makes you run around way too much. It feels like this game is designed to deliberately waste your time. First of all, there is no map feature. No compass of any sort. I sometimes agree that map is distracting in a HUD, but this game requires you countless times to obtain a specific item (those ♥♥♥♥ing sticks) in a dungeon in order to progress to the next part. Without a map, you will make a wrong turn occasionally. Sometimes you are just completely lost and you have to go through every room to find the place you want to go. There should at least be some kind of indicator for me to find my way back to my objectives, but there is none.The WORST THING about this game is how useless the waypoint gates are. They are completely not accessible at all. It's like a handicap parking stall with only enough space to park a small hatchback. Seriously, it makes me mad everytime i see one waypoint because they are useless. Unlike waypoints in other free roaming rpg games, you cannot use them to travel freely between waypoints. It's only use is to take you back to your tower (home). Well wtf, now they just waste my time for no reason. But wait, it's EVEN WORSE than that. From your tower, you can only teleport to major towns (which so far I only have three) and the last visited dungeon. The lifeforces (used to summon minions) are area specific, so when you run out, even when you know where to find them, you cannot go there directly. You have to teleport one of your major waypoints (which all of them are super far away from the location you want to go) and WALK. This is very serious, this is like the game breaking flaw that might render this game unplayable.Finally, the puzzles in the game are quite dull (so far). Feels like a cookie cutter design. It follows a formula of: you can't pass area until you get the red minion. You get the red minion, but look this green gas will require you to get the green minion to pass. so on and so forth. Even after I unlocked all 4 minions, the puzzles are still boring.This game is not bad by all means, but it could use a lot of serious work. Now I feel really relucant to continue playing because I feel this problem will add onto itself when I unlock even more playable areas. I really don't want to waste time doing things that make me not enjoy the game. Plus that old imp is just ♥♥♥♥ing annoying. Try it out if you have the $$$ since its not that expensive, but if your serious about how your time is spent, stay the heck away from this.

number of helpful: 14 of 50 people (28%) found this review helpful
content:
r 30, 2014
												This is my very first review.The premise of this game was rather intriguing. You control little little minions to do your biding, ala pikmin style. Except you're evil. Really evil. There is even a mechanic where if you go out of your way to do evil things, such as kill peasants, you receive a certain percentage of corruption. This corruption ultimately determines a 100% chaotic ending, or a good ending. If you lean towards being good, the appearance of the overlord changes. If you however choose to do evil deeds, such as kill NPCs, your appearance will also change. Spikes grow out of your armor and the overlord emits an unsettling red glow.. As charming as this all was, many things brought down my experience with this game. 1. Combat & Controls. Oh dear, the combat. It feels quite clunky. Especially how the overlord swings his weapon. It feels as though it doesn't have much weight to it. You have one standard combo. Also, attack is bound to the spacebar with no way to rebind keys! In no way is this acceptable! I would prefer to attack with my left mouse button. I know that the minions are supposed to fight for you, however, I would at times like to do some fighting of my own. Controlling the minions wasn't so bad at first, until I was controlling a large swarm of them. The clunkyness of the controls becomes evident later on as you gain access to more minions. You are however able to split them up into groups, which helps to a certain degree, but I still had issues when I would have 30-40 of each, all trying to collect something or kill a big monster. It felt like attempting to control a mouse through a maze that has a strong will of its own. You want it to do this, or go this way, but it just won't obey.2. Graphics: Being a seven-year-old game, it will of course not look as gorgeous as modern games. The art style is charming and fits a comical fantasy world such as this. I find certain character models to be humorous, especially the halfings. There are graphical issues, though. All of which I will mention below under the bugs section. 3. Level-design: This aspect of the game really affected my enjoyment. Areas were quite large, thus requiring much backtracking. One of my main gripes in any game is excessive backtracking. About halfway through, I was in a forest. Without giving away any major spoilers, the task at hand was to take down some roots connected to a peculiar tree. Halfway through this ordeal, I had to go to an entirely new area to gain new minions just so I could progress in the previous aforementioned area. While it is nice to be introduced to new areas, having to move onto a new one abruptly was jarring. 4. Characters & Story: I wish the overlord could speak. It would make for some interesting situations. While some interactions are amusing, most of the characters are forgettable, annoying, or just plain cheesy. As for the story, you are given quests for each area with more quests given to you along the way, which all contribute to a story in each area. Which, in turn, contributes to the overarching story of the big evil baddy conquering the world. There however isn't much to the story, nor much depth. A shame since a story is a big aspect when it comes to the overall experience of a game such as this.5. Bugs: This is what truly broke my experience with the game. At times there would be graphical glitches. Parts of the ground would't render properly as well as walls. There were Random crashes aplenty as well as random slowdowns on a high-end computer. Then came the infamous elevator bug Elevator Bug: In order to progress in a later part of the game, you are required to find two missing levers to complete a rotating wheel. This wheel is used to raise an elevator. With the levers found, I directed my minions to move the wheel. The elevator arose. But something was wrong. When I tried to go inside, it would not go to the next area. I tried leaving the area, going back to the tower, even exiting the game and going back. Nothing worked. While not everyone may encounter this bug, is it one I encountered that stifled my ability to even finish the game.Sidequest Bug: For contribution to the 100% chaotic ending, there is a sidequest in the starting area where you have the option to capture maidens for your tower. You must capture 10 of these maidens spread throughout the area. After finding 7/10, I came upon the next two. So I did what any overlord would do: Swarm them with 50 minions and have them carry her to the nearest portal! Muahaha! But, something was wrong. My minons carried both maidens to one specific spot and then they wouldn't budge. I ordered different minions to carry them. I captured them out of order. I exited the game and went back in. No matter what, they would always carry them to the same spot and not move. Thus, I was unable to finish the sidequest.TLDR Version:While this game starts out enjoyable with many quirks and amusing moments, it is full of many issues. Most of which become prevalent as your progress. The incessant bugs, controls, excessive backtracking, lack of intriguing characters and story as well as repetitiveness ultimately bring this game down. I unfortunately cannot recommend this game.

content:
er 6, 2014
												Overlord is an action/strategy hybrid that has you ordering masses of weak minions about as an equally weak evil (or just evilish, depending on how you respond to the binary "choice" system) Overlord (heh, eh). Without your minions you suck, and small masses or individual minions suck worse. However, together you and the little red/green/brown/blue imps can form an unbeatable team of chaos...so long as you can master the controls and don't have too many technical issues.The worst thing about this game are the controls. Overlord is an experience that demands a level of precision and skill that my controller and I are incapable of. Initially pleasant and open levels give way to tight-corners and enemy puzzles that require quick and accurate adaptation on the fly, yet the camera is incapable of keeping up. On the controller, the stick you would normally use for controlling the camera is used to guide your brain-challenged minions around the environment. Using the mouse allows for easier camera control, but I couldn't "send" my minions at anything when I tried it. The camera follows either you or a minion you're controlling, and if you're trying to move and control minions at the same time in tight spaces it has a tendency to freak out or try abrupt and nauseating angles. The camera has two settings, behind the back and top-down, but neither is useful.A terrible camera isn't a killer, but poor minion controls are. Later levels have you coordinating your four minion types by role: Greens back stab, Blues heal, Reds throw fireballs, and Browns soak up damage. You can pin and recall groups of minions to/from spots, but while the pin function is individual to your selected units the recall function will recall ALL units, which can easily and quickly ruin any plans you might have. The challenge of the game exacerbates this, as all minions but the Browns die extremely easily. The Blues are almost useless if not for their healing, and many enemies in later levels are entirely immune to the Reds. Additionally, the only way you may replenish your army is by killing certain enemies, while every new encounter seems designed to go through a sizable number of minions to just get it done (figuring everything out is usually the easy part). So, by the second to last boss fight I managed to run entirely out of the only minion who could do reliable damage to ANYTHING in the level, and the only way to earn my minions back would be through extensive, boring, stupid, ugly grinding.Finally, the game lags on my computer. Mostly it seems related to if/when I run ANYTHING in the background, but other times it slows down for no apparent reason. It's extremely odd, and makes no sense given the number of things I can otherwise run just fine.I want to recommend Overlord for the opportunity to play the leader of a mob of idiots, but the controls just ruin everything.

31, 2015
												overlord is probably one of the worst games I've ever played. I am writing this review, begging people not to suffer through it. The controls are confusing and never work right. The combat is so unbelievably boring that you dread every fight, and there are enemies constantly, making the game extremely annoying. The fights seem to play out randomly too. Sometimes, you can breeze through enemies no problem, but if you die or restart, the same place could feature a completely new set of rules. Many times have I restarted somewhere after killing several enemies with ease, to find much stronger enemies of the same type that constantly respawn. Who needs consistency i guess? The minions themselves are impossible to control. Each color does something unique in combat, but they never seem to want to do it. Instead they will just stand there and let themselves die. They are supposed to attack automatically when set to a marker, but that is rare. The game has some good qualities, but I can't seem to remember them over all the bad. There are several weapons and armor you can upgrade to, and you can imbue them with powers depending on what minions you put into them. These powers do not work. So there goes that nice feature. There is a variety of spells, but I can't ever remember which F key is which of the 12 and I just end up forgetting about them entirely. Some of the spells are confusing to use also and they all drain your mana so quickly, there's almost no point in using them anywayAnd the game is looooongggg. Maybe...I 'm not sure actually. Yeah it is, 20 hours in and I'm almost done, I think. It just feels super long because its so dull and boring. It feels like it never ends. There is no story driving the game, you just kind of walk around (very slowly I might add) and just do stuff, killing enemies over and over. The worst part is the game starts out ok, but the more I play it, the more I hate it. If I didn't beat every game I buy, I would have quit this one long ago.

												You play as an all powerful lord of chaos and evil. Except for instead of chaos and evil, you're forced to do good deeds for unless you want to get awful rewards and make the game a bigger pain in the ♥♥♥ than it already is (which makes the entire premise of the game a lie), and instead of being all powerful, you die in about 3 hits unless you have your annoying goblin minions do everything for you by controlling them in an RTS fashion. This isn't an RTS, it's a 3rd person game, where the camera is behind your character (who moves like he desperately needs to find a toilet), and in 3rd person games, manually tracing a path for NPCs doesn't work. Neither does setting them up in strategic spots. Neither does selecting between multiple units. You want a game where you play as an all powerful evil dude? Go track down a copy of Destroy All Humans. You want an RTS game where you can control evil factions? Go get one of the Dawn of War games. But don't buy this piece of ♥♥♥♥.

ry 5, 2014
												I totally agree with those that complained about a lack of a map, or even a quest indicator... I wasted SO MUCH TIME wandering around trying to find what I'm supposed to do next (the quest list gives you nothing).  The game is appallingly lacking in any direction, instruction, and guidance.  Eg. Some areas will indicate where you are going when moving from one zone to the next, by showing what that area is, but most DON'T.  You have to blindly wander to the new zone, wait for it to load, see whats there, then have to retreat (and another load), because it wasnt where you wanted to go.At one point the game crashed out on me (just after getting the red minions), and now I cant get them again, cant find anything else to do that doesn't require them.  ABSOLUTE WASTE OF TIME.  Ive tried playing this game a few times over the years, and every time it ends up just being a boring wander around the countryside.  Its a great concept, nice graphics and sounds, and a sense of humour, but the playability aspect SUCKS, the controls are dodgy and cannot be easily changed, difficulty curves are all over the place (mostly too easy, then some too hard).  There is no story either (at least as far as I've been able to tolerate playing this piece of crap).  Don't waste your money or the download... I made the mistake of purchasing Overlord 2 also, and don't think Ill even bother to look at it.

, 2014
												This is an amazingly fun game. The graphics are beautiful for its time and it reminds one of Fable when playing. (Though I'm not 100% sure, I believe some of the same voice actors are present in this game)  Basically, you are awakened as the new Overlord and your first priority is to retrieve the 3 lost Minion clans which each have special powers of their own. Browns (Your starters) have all the power. Greens (Your assassins) are a lethal group, though they can't take the hits as much as the browns. Reds ( Can dish out the long distant damage and are great for area advantages such as ledges and whatnot) One hit and they are goners. Lastly, the Blues (Revivers) that's pretty much all they can, oh and they're the only ones who can defeat magical creatures.6 hours in and there is already a mass amount of content. For starters, you can customize your very own tower. Everything from banner colors to so much more. Then there is the arena, in which you and your minion horde takes on foes in which you've already defeated. There is the smelter, in which you make new armour/weapons and upgrade your current armour/weapons as well as your minions attack and defense as well. And also..well so far..that's I'll I've gotten.It's exciting viewing the beautiful scenery as well as the hearing the crude humor which this game offers. It's a great laugh. Though there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of story present, that's not a problem. You are mostly doing random quests and deciding whether or not to grow your corruption level. Killing equals more corruption. Not killing..is pretty much being good. There is quite a bit of strategy involved which is nice. Example, certain trolls will wave their arms before hurdling themselves in the air and doing body slams. Your job is to notice this signal, call your minions back (sparing them such a horrible fate) an finally throwing them back in their after it's landed. Figuring these things out is exciting on it's own. Overall, the Fable nostalgic feel I get from the graphics and certain characters in this game make it a pretty great game, for me at least. Also, the gameplay as well. I start feeling connected to my little guys and though it's not necessary, I always tend to see myself in the mix of battle. The content which you get for the price in fantastic, but if you want more, it's worth the cash to get Raising Hell instead, simply because it's an expansion to this game.The only cons for this game involve the random minion glitches. Occasionally, the minions will be carrying items and simply stop. Even if nothing is blocking their paths. Also, minions themselves tend to get stuck in or under objects as well, but not too often. This usually occurs when some of your other minions are carrying items and they just happen to get in the way. Overall, They do a phenomenal job following your orders, only 1 time have I had a minion lost and I've had to backtrack it.

ry 13, 2014
												Holds up surprisingly well, with engaging gameplay including halfway decent, not puzzles exactly, things like puzzles with your minion control (tho one or two frustrating moments) and above-all the humour. The humour is what sells this game.Given that FUN is what many (almost all) consider the point of video games (and that's wrong mind, but irrelevent here), you'd really expect more games to be funny. I really don't get why they're so sparse. Granted, big difference between comedic elements, comic relief, and comedy -- even bigger difference between a comedy and a full-blown . . .giggle-fest? Yeah, giggle-fest. This game is a comedy, through and through -- in an almost classical (Greek) sense actually. Snarky wit, situational juxtaposition, exaggeration, and something that in a twisted way could actually be called romance. Basic RPG elements, and that's all it needed -- it's a nice little adventure. Cheers for a good romp and no few laughs.

												Enjoyed Pikmin, but hated the cutesey visuals and creatures at your command? Enjoyed Dungeon Keeper, but wanted a more hands on approach to being a dispicable ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? Then do I have the game for you.A PC that's a walking Sauron Expy with a horde of derranged, specialized and color coded for you convience Minions in a world where good has gotten fat, lazy and corrupt without a decent evil force to rally against and a decently challenging puzzle and combat system await you in Overlord.

22, 2014
												Great fun! Minnions are so well developed, with personality, wit, and very funny actions. The story is well told but a bit lite. The world is very well designed and allows plenty of adventuring and revisiting areas is even encouraged. The colors and objects are bright and bold. This game takes some tactical strategy to play well. You can fight each encounter in many different styles depending how you mix and match your 4 different minnion types. They four are very different and your decision on how many of each type to travel with changes every encounter. There isn't another game like this ... and that uniqueness really makes this game stand out. The RPG element of improving your armor and weapons also extends to improving your different minnions and your own magic spells. I played for hours just because it was so much fun. I never felt compelled to advance the story any faster than I felt like going. The replay value of this game is very high. Even when you know all the plot points that will advance the story there is still some much variety that you can try to complete area's time and again with different mixes of minions and new tactics. I was very surprised at the quality and pure fun of this game.   This game is a 9 out of 10. Very fun, very replayable, very enjoyable ... when your brown minnion returns with a pumpkin on it's head as a helmet ... what's not to like?

												That was great! Pikmin in the style of Fable plus Dungeon Keeper. What's not to like? Well, you could nitpit and say that there's no minimap, plus the tutorialization is broken in a couple of key places (how to sweep and how to use guard markers). And there's no Run speed, so you're going to be doing a lot of trogging around. But your minions are SO MUCH FUN. You won't feel so much evil as much-loved in this game. Your minions just adore you, bringing you stuff and eagerly praising you in every way. Plenty of lovely details, plus some gorgeous worlds, make this a game I found well worth playing.

ber 7, 2014
												Overlord is certainly worth playing. It has good gamplay and a nice chunk of humour. Keep in mind though that there is no serious plot in it, as it relies on its humour. In the game you control minions along with the main character, which is, the Overlord. The Overlord is fairly squishy alone, but is capable of doing decent damage. This is where the minions come handy. They can overwhelm opponents with their numbers, leaving the Overlord out of harms way. There are four types of minions. Brown, Red, Green and Blue. Every type has their own special abilities and uses. Brown minions lack a special quality, but are the thoughest in a fight. Reds throw fireballs, are immune to fire and can extinguish fires blocking your way. Greens are immune to poison and can remove toxic fumes. Blues can go into water without drowning. Then there is your tower. In the tower you can forge armor and weapons for the Overlord to use, customize its looks and you can even get a mistress there. Yay. There is also a teleporter, which you can use to get to places you have visited previously.The music in this game fits it very well. The soundtrack is not awesome, but as stated, it fits the games setting and helps set up the atmosphere. Visuals are nice for such a old game. The animations looked a bit awkward in certain situations, but it kind of just adds to the humour. One might even think that they were made awkward on purpose. Heh.Overall this game has a lot of good points and a very few bad ones. The controls for the gamepad did feel a bit "iffy", so I'd recommend using a keyboard and a mouse. If I had to name to biggest issue I have with the game, I'd have to say it's the fact that you can't save manually. Anywho, this game is definetly worth picking up if you're looking for a humorous and lighthearted RPG.

												OverlordWhen this game was released back in 2007 and me and my friends popped into the pc, we went like "wow that looks good"4 years later... it still looks really good!Imagine a fantasy world, with dwarfs, elfes, halflings humans etc.Its a perfect little world, but every world needs its balance.Thats where you come in, Evil recarnated, you are the new OVERLORD.Subdue the mindless mortals to your will, make them fear you or love you, as long as they worship you.Follow a questline that requires you to hunt down and deal with the group of heroes that defeated the last Overlord before you.The game has a great world design, and really sets the mood, also the story line fits right with the theme, and the choices you make influence the outcome.Choose to be good or evil, command an army of minions, at the end of the game you will be sad its over.I played this game countless time and im still not tired of it! 10/10

												An  entertaining cross between Lord of the rings/dungeons and dragons and Pikmin! Although most of the things in game can and should be done by your disposable and often easily replaceable minions, you can step in and get involved in the battles directly. Different colour minions have different strengths, weaknesses and abilities that should be used to tip the tides in your favour. Although it shows it's age in places it still looks good and the sounds and music are suitable. Some of the voice acting could have been done better and possibly more varied within a species.The controls benefit greatly from the use of a game pad, and the game has very good support needing a keyboard for first time setup and player profile creation only.The game has a known bug that causes errors on launch if you own but have not downloaded the 'Raising Hell' expansion.Overall this is a game that you find in the 'bargain bin' but soon discover it's simple yet devious play style getting you gripped for hours.

ber 6, 2015
												A game where you get to control a super-villain whose only goal is to control the entire world, either with total dominion in mind or to bend the entire world beneath your iron grip. You have a plethora of minions that serve and do your bidding, and overall, I don't have ANY complaints about this game other than the odd glitch where your minion gets permanently stuck somewhere and you're stuck without them until you exit the area and come back in or go to a new zone.Combat is primarily focused on you controlling your minions as you don't really have much in the way of fending off enemies aside from swinging your weapon or casting the odd spell at them. The boss battles are actually pretty good, though my favorite one has to be the first boss because I love dodging around him and then siccing the minions onto his butt and watching them climb all over him and beat on him until he shakes them off. Oh, did you know your minions can jump onto enemies and beat them senseless too? Vicious little things.All in all, I heavily recommend this game for anyone looking to get into the Overlord series. For me, this game will always be a 10 out of 10, the only game that beats it in pure evil mastermindery is Dungeon Keeper.

												This game is fantastic. It is packed with some decently dark and impish humour, the setting is glorious and the gameplay is fun and addicting. Unlike other games, which put you in place of the hero, you deliberately play a villain in this one. Why is that so important? Because this game lets you play this role any way you like. Keep the civilians alive and you get access to certain areas and some upgrades, kill them off and you get corrupt, causing you to become stronger yourself. Every choice you make has an impact on the game world, and this game knows how to make you feel that it actually had an impact.The gameplay needs some minor tweaking on the minions' AI, but else it plays well, even with the Keyboard and Mouse. The controls are complex, yet easy to learn, and it has a significant level of challenge at some points in the game.The graphics still hold up today, which is a hard thing for a game from 8 years ago. And best of all: You can even kick your own minions around if you feel like beating someone's face without killing anyone.- - - - - - - - - -Gameplay: 8/10Controls: 8/10Difficulty: 7/10Graphics: 9/10Addictive: Definitely, it's so much fun to play- - - - - - - - - -Worth buying: Of course. Just the minion-kicking is worth the money alreadySo what are you waiting for? If you ever wanted to play the villain in charge of a minion horde, kill some sheep for fun (and more minions), slice and dice some villagers and rule the world, this game is for you

r 1, 2016
												Not bad for a game made almost 10 years ago. I've seen this game pop up in my suggestions list several times, but never really gave it a second look until a rainy day at home a few days ago. The overall premise is different, placing you as the tyrannical dictator who is happy to sacrifice your minions to get upgrades to your armor, destroy your enemies or just for laughs. As you complete quests you unlock different types of minions who carry out your bidding on the battle field, and also restore your looted and dilapidated castle to its former glory. You are encouraged to be evil, which is a nice change of pace from the games that give the tired option of choosing good over bad (i.e. Fable, KOTOR, etc). Sometimes, it’s nice to have a linear story line that takes you down a specific path to show you something fun.The game play is addicting, though a little buggy when trying to control your horde, and the control mapping wasn't ported very well to my Mac (namely the function keys which have operations assigned to them through mac os). But you can map the controls yourself and find a way to play the game that works best for you. The game also crashes periodically for unknown reasons, but I'm sure an update will fix that in the near future.For the price, Overlord is worth your time.

Product received for free
												So far I'm enjoying the game. Very fun and humorous. However, the game-play is incredibly clunky and annoying.The whole game mechanic is a nuisance! controls and game mechanics are awkward and annoying. If you wan to heal, you'd have to find a specific statue that's used to sacrifice minions in order to gain health. The same thing goes for raising your mana. This task can be awfully annoying when you're being chased by enemies, have have one minion left, and you're running low on health. It's honestly mixed emotions for me.  Like, why couldn't they just have health and mana potions? It drives me freaking nuts!!! I technically have 7 hours into the game. A friend gifted it to me, which too came with the DLC; (Overlord: Raising Hell), oddly enough it comes as a whole standalone game... Meaning if you lunch the original game it'll exe the dlc game instead. Hence why it shows my played time as 0.4 hrs. Anyway, I seriously don't know why they can't just get the DLC launched with the main game?! What's so hard about that? Something else that really bothers me is the map-level design. Like I mentioned the controls are clunky and annoying, and maybe it's a me thing, but I find my self absolutely lost and confused on what to do next in some levels. And I kid you not, I literally look at every edges of the map just to try and find a clue on what to do. The game is just poorly made. The awkward camera disorients the hell out of me therefore makes it hard to have real perspective of the game's level. Again, this could just be a me thing. But my point stands the game plays like crap. After all I said, I still get called back into it. The game has interesting chemistry, the visual arts remind me of Fable 2, the music is great. Maybe one of the best I've heard in games.(Here's a playlist of the game's soundtrack on YouTube)(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a3o2Xr3Jp34&list=PL8E804F42C3BB9E24) The game is simple, it doesn't ask much of you. You're just some big bad-♥♥♥ dude with a big ♥♥♥ axe that commands funny little minions dudes to your bidding. If that isn't good enough you have 11 unique domains to explore (6 with main game and 5 with DLC). And you can be A. A good guy that helps the weak in help or B. Be a cruel jerk and off them and keep everything to yourself. If you appreciate a game with nice visual arts, great music and incredibly annoying game-play mechanics and control maybe this game is for you? I'm not sure what this is, I don't think it's a review. I think a honest review is of someone giving unbiased statements and facts about said subject. There is a bit of biasm here. But whatever, if you like what you read watch a few game play videos and then buy the game. It's only $5 and you could also refund it in time. Just thought I'd share my thoughts.

												Ah, this is one of my favorite game next to Dungeon Keeper (there really needs to be sequel). You awaken out of a special tomb, brought back to life by the adorable yet deadly minions you will soon command. One unique Minion, Gnarl, helps guide you through your rise to power, as you take over the nearby peacefull village and make your own decision as to wether you will be a gentle master, or a dominating overlord that leaves a swatch of destruction behind. Your corruption is measured as you progress, and retrieve the hives of your various minions. Learn to use each to maximum effectiveness and outfit your hoarde with a number of each. Will you take over the entire kingdom? Upgrade your amor, and weapons, or look for special objects that increase your health, mana, or hoarde size. Lots to explore and do allover the kingdom, and it's all yours. Once you take it, that is.

8, 2015
												A mix of action and strategy, where you play the titular overlord and command a group of minions to do your bidding. Although fun and engaging, and offering an interesting art design, the story is lacking, but at least it's humorous. If you ever played Pikmin, this game plays in a very similar fashion, but is not cutesey, which I find to be a big plus. Overall, I had a lot of fun playing, the biggest drawback to me is a lack of replayability. You have a few choices to make in the game, and they do affect the game to some degree, but they're pretty superficial, and did not make me want to see what happens if I choose differently too much. Despite all that, the game has a certain charm to it that made me love the game despite it's shortcomings. Also, of all the games which have a villain protagonist this is the best one of the bunch, maybe the sequel is even better, but I have yet to play it.

												This game has everything i loved about Dungeon Keeper, except rather than possessing a minion im just an evil dungeon overlord with a choice of feindish weapons, magic and an army of imps to do my despicable bidding.Manage your minions with a combination of squad-command styled combat and third person action, that plays decently for a game that i suspect was a console - > pc port, albiet that the controls can be clumsy at times though, so consider yourself warned.Gather gold, unlock more minions and raise your hellish army of, i daresay for evil ... some of the little buggers are amusingly cute... and rebuild your lair while you raid and pillage the outlying towns, showing no mercy to all those in your way.Id recommend the game just for the dark humor honestly and the fact that for once, you get to play evil, but those are also somethings that i loved from Bullfrog's Dungeon Keeper series - but this isnt about DK, this is about a rather enjoyable melee/squad/3rd person action game called Overlord!

2, 2015
												Overlord is a game I want to like but that I fail to. The premise is sound: you are an evil Overlord who commands an army of minions and seeks to do evil deeds across an otherwise rather peaceful land. Which could be fun, if the game didn't get in the way. To rebind the keyboard controls you have to open up a seperate configuration window that has drop-down menus as opposed to the standard 'click-and-select' method most games use. On top of that the key-binds only appear to take some of the time. Now if you're like me and own a controller you might think yourself smart in using it, except that the controller controls are just as bad. The right-analog stick doesn't turn the camera and thus you're left to the mercy of when the game deicides you need to turn. The minion controls work reasonably well but I found it very removed and it felt more like an RTS with a third-person camera. The game is awfully vague at times as well and you'll find yourself without an idea of what you're supposed to be doing, how to go about doing it or what your overall goal is.

												For a fan of any game; with it's dark humour, reasonable storyline and tactical combat, there's everything you could hope to find in a game. Truly, one of the greatest ever. It is fun, unique, creative and certainly makes you aware of what you're doing - you feel like you're in control of the game, everything comes down to what you decide to do. All in all, thoroughly enjoyed each and every aspect of the game, it is excellent! The Raising Hell expansion adds even greater things. You'll be frustrated at the inability of minions to protect themselves and to carry out attacks when the enemies start mob actions. Another issue that I have personally had with minion controls, are their ability to not follow your command fast enough and this will cause ALOT of anger. But If you can get over these issues, the game is great.

It surprised me how a 7 year old game can still offer the same caliber of entertainment that one can expect from current titles. 												Now, I was expecting a whole lot from this one, as I can even see that Jim Sterling recommended it. After beating it I can say it's not bad at all. If you liked Fabel, you will love this. You play a rescued Overlord who is made to rule over his minions. The gameplay is alot like a hack and slash RPG meets Strategy. The games currency is split into Gold and Life force. You need lifeforce to spawn minions, so you can expect a bit of grinding....Yeah the game gets that whole "Third Person action game with RTS elements" right, unlike Brutal Legends. Controlling minions takes a bit of learning, but once you get the hang of it, it's not bothersome at all.The real joy is the core parts of the game i.e. the minion controlling and puzzling. The remaining parts of the game aren't exciting...I'm talking about the action, story, upgrading and customizing part. The Upgrading and customizing part are More like "They're there so I'll take it". The Overlords combat mechanics are silly, but minions make up for it.Lastly, the part about you being Evil. It doesn't get portrayed well. All you feel is Anti-Heroish. It always comes out as you are a jerk who does good and is saving the world.

ry 28, 2016
												This game. Aight? THIS game. Lets you become an overlord.I mean sure, it's the only successful Overlord game that CodeMasters made at the time I am writing this review, but this one holds a special place near my heart.So here is my review of the game!-Synopsis-Basically, you play as an amnesiac that has been saved by these little goblins/gremlins/imps/fiends known as 'minions'. ... And no, not the yellow pill/potato shaped guys in the Despicable Me Franchise. Technically, this game came before Despicable Me, so I would like to think that Gru is more ripping off of the Overlord. The guy YOU play as. He is ripping YOU off! ... But anyway...As a result from being saved by them, they expect you to command the horde around for the purposes of killing your foes, breaking objects, stealing valuables, and harvesting resources.Kill your enemies with an axe, the most balanced melee weapon you can wield in the early game, where later, you can upgrade the weapon or get new weapons made from better metals with better smelters you find in your travels. Or alternatively, use your minions to kill your enemies for you. They are the backbone to your evil rule after all! But if you find that your enemies need a more 'personal touch', magic adds a little salt to their injury.-Pros-The gameplay is wonderfully simple, as all you need to do is just be evil! The game even gives you the choice of being merciful or tyrannical. Choosing the corrupted tyrannical path has instant gratification and can get you a lot of resources early. Or you can choose to be merciful. I won't judge you if you would rather save some people and forgo the money. ... But it's still a waste of that money that would be more useful being in your treasury.Simply put, you are the Overlord, and you lay waste to the land on how you see fit.And the DLC known as Raising Hell? A recommendable buy as it adds more items and more places to adventure.-Cons-This game goes far back to the age of 2007, so expect the graphics and animations to be slightly... lackluster. The control scheme on the keyboard feels unwieldy than being on the controller since I can look freely around using the mouse, though using the F1-F12 keys to select spells felt very awkward. This game WAS designed to be played on a controller of course.Then there is the grind for resources. Ooooooh the grinding can take a long time if you don't know what your doing. Even though the resources are easy to get, they usually come in small quantities in most areas, and one would find oneself returning to your tower and then coming back to the land to raid more things. Or simply go to the dungeon and fight enemies in there. Another sad con that I noticed was that there is absolutely no mana regeneration. I mean sure, you can find mana potions in chests and can sacrifice minions to a mana pit to regain mana, or alternatively go back into your dark tower to instantly restore all your health and mana. There is even an armor upgrade that enables you to regenerate your health, but not your mana for some reason. And I do like to cast my most destructive spells sometimes.:3-Rating-I give this game a 4/5, and recommend this game to those who would want to tickle the evil bone in their body someday.(Hell, I even like this game so much that I wrote some fanfiction on it. YES. FANFICTION. I ADMITTED IT.)

												The game "Dungeon Keeper" by Bullfrog Productions changed dungeon crawling into dungeon creating whereby the player was the evil at the heart of the dungeon and the goal was to stop the heroes. "Overlord" is another variation of taking the player out of the role of being the hero and into the shoes of the bad guy.  The game parodies the typical heroic RPG and the goal is to conquer the lands surrounding your great evil tower, which you can upgrade using the treasures you collect. Also, there are decorative options to get your tower looking good as well.You can control vast armies of goblins to terrorize the people, collect treasures, and burn villages but to what degree is up to you. The goblins will often make silly comments or jesters while adventuring or pillaging which will make you laugh and chuckle to the very end.There are various options for upgrading your equipment using the forge in the tower while the goblins automatically equip gear found during raids on the villages or you can direct the horde with a mouse click to a stash of gear to which they plunder and equip if possible—I saw one goblin put a pumpkin on its head for a helmet.The controls for the horde of goblins are very simple and easy to navigate. You even have the option of splitting the horde into smaller groups and covering more area. Several puzzles will make for a challenge and require you to adjust the type of goblin in your group like melee, range, or magic in order to move forward.While the main goal is to conquer the lands through ruthlessness or mercy, you also have achievements you can collect and a statistics which shows the amount of total devastation you brought upon the people, which encourages replay.I recommend the game if you want an action-adventure and RPG game that is hilariously witty but challenging. I also recommend purchasing the expansion which adds even more entertainment and fun.

												Old, sometimes frustrating if you don't know what you are doing but veryfunny if you like some dark humor.Overlord 2 is much better, but this game is a rough gem as far as I'm concerned and a great part one in the series.It still looks quite good and plays well as long as you use a gamepad, preferrably one with the xbox button layout or with a programmable layout so you can match the Minions to the correct buttons on the pad.The minions are a great idea, making for some unique ways of solving the in game quests.They can fight for you, throw levers, get trough narrow gaps to attack an enemy from behind and be used as traps to ambush the enemies you just lured to them with some other minions.If you get adept at controlling them your dark lord will often never need to lift a gauntleted finger to defeat a lot of the foes in the game. And they are just so incredibly enthousiastic at sacrificing themselves for you that you just have to smile (In an evil way of course).You will even use them to create better armor and weapons for your lord by throing them directly in the furnace in your forge.The game world is a nice "classical fantasy gone wrong" wher you finally get to play as absolute evil, or just slightly evil if you prefer. Both have their up and down side.True, hearing "For YOUUUUU!" a lot can get a bit annoying at times, but that is a common problem with soundbytes in games isn't it.If you can get it with the expansion pack, do so because it contains a few of the most excellent levels in the game and leads to the events of Overlord 2.

Intuitive control of your minions, a kind of rock-paper-scissors approach to puzzles/enemies, and semi-open ended quests make the game engaging from start to finish. Its main strength is in its presentation. The potshots it takes at fantasy tropes is great, and worth the price of admission. It doesn't take itself too seriously, while at the same time going for that epic sweep. It pulls that off admirably. And for once, it's funner to be evil.  Great stuff.

ry 22, 2015
												Man, what to say about this game.I had never heard of it before I bought it. But seeing how it was only a dollar, and has very favorable reviews, I decided to take the plunge and blow my pocket change. Let me tell you, that was the best dollar I ever spent. This game is just amazing, addicting, and hilarious. It is a parody/satire of the traditional RPG genre, and at the same time somewhat of a RTS. Even though the graphics are a little dated, you won't notice once you start smashing villages and goons around with your gremlin army. In most ways it is just a normal RPG, while there is no "leveling", there are upgrades to make you more powerful for your armor and your minions, who will be doing mostly ALL of the fighting for you. Infact, your character is really just there to provide support, as the bulk of the combat is mainly just you micro managing your minions and making sure they dont suicide dive a group of goons. But with that being said, the minions are very well polished and dont often do stupid things unless you tell them too. I really am shocked at how well they are programmed, considering this game is almost 8 years old from the writing of this. It really does hold up very well, and as I am sitting here I can't think of one bad thing that bothered me over the course of me playing it. My favorite part though isn't the unique combat system, but the characters and the world in general. The game is just one big parody on almost every typical RPG ever made. This time around, you are the "anti" hero, whose sole goal is to be evil. But trust me, the only evil that is being done is too your gut, because I found myself laughing very often at the general silliness of the characters and the narration by Gnarl, your guide of all things evil, and the simpletons who guide your quests- erm sorry your "evil" conquests. The whole world is just tongue-in-cheek really, it is just a goofy atmosphere to be in and it is simply marvelous.There really isn't any reason not to buy this game, I can safely say that many people will not have had a previous experience like this before. I sure hadn't and I've been playing RPGs for a very long time and have played QUITE a bit of my fair share of them as well. Even if it's not on sale, I still urge you to take the $5 hit, which is still relatively cheap really for a game of such calliber. I really hate putting numbers on VG reviews, but in this case I will make a rare exception. For the sheer shock of finding such a quality game, and at the price I paid for it. There is only one score I see fit for it.10/10Evil always finds a way ;)

												Great fun! Minnions are so well developed, with personality, wit, and very funny actions. The story is well told but a bit lite. The world is very well designed and allows plenty of adventuring and revisiting areas is even encouraged. The colors and objects are bright and bold. This game takes some tactical strategy to play well. You can fight each encounter in many different styles depending how you mix and match your 4 different minnion types. They four are very different and your decision on how many of each type to travel with changes every encounter. There isn't another game like this ... and that uniqueness really makes this game stand out. The RPG element of improving your armor and weapons also extends to improving your different minnions and your own magic spells. I played for hours just because it was so much fun. I never felt compelled to advance the story any faster than I felt like going. The replay value of this game is very high. Even when you know all the plot points that will advance the story there is still some much variety that you can try to complete area's time and again with different mixes of minions and new tactics. I was very surprised at the quality and pure fun of this game.   This game is a 9 out of 10. Very fun, very replayable, very enjoyable ... when your brown minnion returns with a pumpkin on it's head as a helmet ... what's not to like?

y 19, 2015
												Do you ever wanted to be the bad guy? Do you ever admired the Dark Lord, looking badass, destroying world and killing those pesky heroes? Well, then, this game is for you! Without further delay, lets sink into the fantastic (and sarcastic) world of Overlord!The "bad guy" game market is severelly limited. Everywhere we are feeded with either Goody McGood heroes, fighting to save the world or with shallow concept of being gray and developing our character the way we want to (shallow being either ♥♥♥♥ing rainbows knight in shining armor or baby killing maniac). You wont see that here. Instead, we are evil from the start. And that's what making this game fun.Gameplay is really basic sadly. We are the Overlord. We need to rebuild empire. But Overlord doesn't just go around killing stuff, oh no. He have his minions for that. So we are running around with bunch of our Imps, killing things, collecting stuff to upgrade our tower and (of course) doing some fairly easy puzzles. The style is kinda like Zelda. We need some item or other thing to advance further, we collect it, defeat the boss with that, go to another area, rince and repeat. Graphics are really beatiful. This game aged well, giving nice vibe even so long after the golden release. Locations are colorful and alive yet distinct, there are things moving everywhere, light effects are well made. The olny thing I can really dissaprove of are the overall sugar-like appearances of every single location, but the game have it's (gigantic dose) of humour, and exaggeration pays a big role in that.Music is on par with graphics. Really exaggerated, yet well made and distinct. Sounds are great. Every single detal from random people dialogs to battle sounds are great. Story is great. We are the Overlord, taking over the world yet again. At our path there will be much obstacles, including corrupted heroes, lack of resources and other natural or unnatural calamities. Narration is smooth and plot twists are well done. We even have the pleasure of having a wife here, and Overlord is not your average multihour RPG.Bad things? Well, for starters all our work is done by minions. I won't say its technically bad, but our Overlord can't do crap. Its kind of stupid, we are the antihero of this world. The other thing, because the game is strongly influenced by Zelda franchise, we can't really talk about open world RPG or exploration all that much. Oh, we can go to the previous locations to loot additional stuff with our new powers (it's unattainable otherwise, the easiest example would be Imp Pillars in the water, we can't get them, until we get Blue Imps), but we need to go from point A to B on a series of semi-linear locations in order to progress with the story. Also our Overlord can't be developed all that much. More minions, stronger armor and weapon and minion types. Sadly that's all. Well, if you we're spending all nights in Dungeon Keeper, this game is for you. It have great sense of humor (and a bit of self awareness), nice graphics, enjoyable and easy gameplay, and, of course, you play as the bad guy. Its a good piece, althou technically not a RPG, and sadly, kind of short. But hey, its Zelda on crack, so it can't be all that bad! I would recommend this game to anyone from new to experienced players. Go! Conquer the world, Overlord!Zawisza out.

r 1, 2016
												Not bad for a game made almost 10 years ago. I've seen this game pop up in my suggestions list several times, but never really gave it a second look until a rainy day at home a few days ago. The overall premise is different, placing you as the tyrannical dictator who is happy to sacrifice your minions to get upgrades to your armor, destroy your enemies or just for laughs. As you complete quests you unlock different types of minions who carry out your bidding on the battle field, and also restore your looted and dilapidated castle to its former glory. You are encouraged to be evil, which is a nice change of pace from the games that give the tired option of choosing good over bad (i.e. Fable, KOTOR, etc). Sometimes, it’s nice to have a linear story line that takes you down a specific path to show you something fun.The game play is addicting, though a little buggy when trying to control your horde, and the control mapping wasn't ported very well to my Mac (namely the function keys which have operations assigned to them through mac os). But you can map the controls yourself and find a way to play the game that works best for you. The game also crashes periodically for unknown reasons, but I'm sure an update will fix that in the near future.For the price, Overlord is worth your time.

Product received for free
												So far I'm enjoying the game. Very fun and humorous. However, the game-play is incredibly clunky and annoying.The whole game mechanic is a nuisance! controls and game mechanics are awkward and annoying. If you wan to heal, you'd have to find a specific statue that's used to sacrifice minions in order to gain health. The same thing goes for raising your mana. This task can be awfully annoying when you're being chased by enemies, have have one minion left, and you're running low on health. It's honestly mixed emotions for me.  Like, why couldn't they just have health and mana potions? It drives me freaking nuts!!! I technically have 7 hours into the game. A friend gifted it to me, which too came with the DLC; (Overlord: Raising Hell), oddly enough it comes as a whole standalone game... Meaning if you lunch the original game it'll exe the dlc game instead. Hence why it shows my played time as 0.4 hrs. Anyway, I seriously don't know why they can't just get the DLC launched with the main game?! What's so hard about that? Something else that really bothers me is the map-level design. Like I mentioned the controls are clunky and annoying, and maybe it's a me thing, but I find my self absolutely lost and confused on what to do next in some levels. And I kid you not, I literally look at every edges of the map just to try and find a clue on what to do. The game is just poorly made. The awkward camera disorients the hell out of me therefore makes it hard to have real perspective of the game's level. Again, this could just be a me thing. But my point stands the game plays like crap. After all I said, I still get called back into it. The game has interesting chemistry, the visual arts remind me of Fable 2, the music is great. Maybe one of the best I've heard in games.(Here's a playlist of the game's soundtrack on YouTube)(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a3o2Xr3Jp34&list=PL8E804F42C3BB9E24) The game is simple, it doesn't ask much of you. You're just some big bad-♥♥♥ dude with a big ♥♥♥ axe that commands funny little minions dudes to your bidding. If that isn't good enough you have 11 unique domains to explore (6 with main game and 5 with DLC). And you can be A. A good guy that helps the weak in help or B. Be a cruel jerk and off them and keep everything to yourself. If you appreciate a game with nice visual arts, great music and incredibly annoying game-play mechanics and control maybe this game is for you? I'm not sure what this is, I don't think it's a review. I think a honest review is of someone giving unbiased statements and facts about said subject. There is a bit of biasm here. But whatever, if you like what you read watch a few game play videos and then buy the game. It's only $5 and you could also refund it in time. Just thought I'd share my thoughts.

er 26, 2016
												One of the best games of its kind, and for once you don't play as the chosen young goodie two shoes kid who saves the world in a fantasy setting, but instead play as a mighty evil overlord who's rising to even greater power.The game tasks you to command 4 different kinds of minions who each have different abilities and strengths; browns, reds, greens and blues.Browns are your basic melee soldiers who are pretty tough and can take more beatings than the other species.Reds are your fireballs throwing artillery, and thus die pretty quickly, they also absorb fire.Greens are your assassins, they love to jump onto the enemies and stab them for tons of damage. They aren't as tough as the browns, but they can take more beatings than blues or reds. They also absorb poison.Blues are your healers, they are terrible at fighting and die quickly, but they will resurrect any fallen minions.All in all the game has a lot of interesting creature designs, is pretty funny sometimes, and you can forge sweet new weapons and armor for your overlord.The only downsides is the minions have a tendency to get stuck in the scenery in one small part of the game.My playtime doesn't accurately reflect the time I've spent on this game as I own a physical copy not registered on Steam too.
