												This is a funny RPG style game.  It's compared often to Fable because you can choose to be good or evil, however I believe the game is designed to be evil specifically.  I found the game to be challenging and entertaining, played it all the way through at least once.  It is linear so replayability suffers, but it was still a fun game.The controls are fairly easy to use, though sometimes it can be a little frustrating if they don't move exactly right.  There's no micromanaging required, the minions pick up things by themselves and show it off as they run around.  Graphics are good, sound is good.  Tons of sarcasm in this game, which I especially like.

y 24, 2015
												Overlord is one of the best games I've ever played! The game is so fun because not only do you feel powerful. but you feel unstoppable! The game has tons of quests! It took me five hours to complete all the quests in  the first area. You can choose to be an evil force to be reckoned or a heroic force to be reckoned with. You can even customize your tower! How freaking cool is that! It's a pretty funny game as well. You can beat the crap out of your court jester, feed your minions and watch them pee after they finish their food and drink, slaughter hobbit-like creatures called halflings and their morbily obese king, and a whole lot more. The game is kind of linear but the areas are pretty big. I say they're linear because usually the way of traveling around are pathways that connect in someway.  Still it doesn't bother me because there is a lot to explore. Now, about forging. Whenever you forge and item whether it be weapons or armor, you have to use minions to do so. The more minions you use the more powerful the item you are making or upgrading will become.Minions come in four types. Brown, red, green, and blue. Brown are your standard minions. They are just mainly used for fighting. Red are invunrable to fire. Green are invunrable to poisonous fumes, and blue can enter water. I highly recommend this game!

er 19, 2015
												Overlord is great. You get to be the bad guy which is always fun, ALWAYS. you can be a caring resposible overlord(yawn) if you really want to or you can bring havoc to the lands and kill all who oppose you, which is much more fun. Sometimes the game reminds me of the lord of the rings trillogy as halflings live in little grass covered houses and the Overlords armour kind of resembles sauron's. its funny how your minions run around for you and destroy everything in their way, even though the minion controls can be a bit buggy at times. Im not that far i only have 3 hours play time and a rough guess would be 25% complete but still a lot of game left. it doesn't have free-roam as such but you can go where ever you like in set areas and levels (which could be considered free roam) and you can travel back and forth to each level once you have been there. You can take the game as slow as you want exploring every room and this is quite often nessesary to find pieces of levers and such. If you want to just speed run through the game the easy mode will let you run through levels with small resistance. So far there hasn't been a lot of story and cut scenes past the opening sequence but that can appeals to some players. Please remember I am not far through the game, things may differ further through so take that into account is you have any problems with this review. Overall overlord is a good game with reasonable graphics for its time. It is 6 years old so some mechanics may be a bit outdated but I haven't encounter any major problems or bugs. This game should run on most systems and is a good buy for all fantasy RPG fans. I would rate this game a 7 with minion controls and some long loading screens being the biggest downfalls but reviewing this in 2015 has obviously impacted the score as games have advanced but this came from an era with still some of the most talked about games to date like skyrim and fallout 3. I'm sure if I was reviewing this when it was released it would have scored a bit higher but as games advanced standards get higher. Overlord is definitely worth picking up and I believe it hasn't had the recognition it deserves but who would play the game properly anyway when you can just kick your court jester around the throne room.

y 27, 2016
												Overlord is one of those games that certainly changes the way you look at how to approach a game. Overlord is what happens when you mix a third person slasher with a very light resource based RTS. Your primary striking force for the vast majority of the game is your minions, and you can spawn increasing amounts as you become more powerful. Each type of minion has different abilities and strengths, and utilizing them correctly can be the difference in total victory or total annhilation.There really isnt much to complain about when taking into consideration the age of the game. Released in 2007, it actually plays pretty well for a game nearly a decade old. Because of its age, the graphics suffer a bit, and there are only 2 movement speeds: walk and walk faster. Something else that could have helped, but wasn't really necessary was the inclusion of a map. Other than that, my only quip is that once you get the hang of how to play the game properly...it becomes very easy.

												"For the Overlorrrd!"This game is an absolute gem. A game where you take on the role of an evil overlord commanding a group of less-than-civil goblins, this game combines interesting story, solid gameplay, and strategy with a taste of laughing gas. It's hard to take anything seriously in this game when your goblin minions are more intent on being silly and disruptive than killing (unless you command them, of course-they always listen to their eeevil Overlord), especially when there's an entire mechanic around booting your minions to the ground. Seriously, those goblins are so adorable, it's actually heartbreaking when one that's been with you on many adventures falls dead. Which happens often.This really is a feel-good game. It's always good for a laugh and brightening your day... although it may be a bit rough jumping back into the middle of it if you take a long hiatus.

er 26, 2016
												One of the best games of its kind, and for once you don't play as the chosen young goodie two shoes kid who saves the world in a fantasy setting, but instead play as a mighty evil overlord who's rising to even greater power.The game tasks you to command 4 different kinds of minions who each have different abilities and strengths; browns, reds, greens and blues.Browns are your basic melee soldiers who are pretty tough and can take more beatings than the other species.Reds are your fireballs throwing artillery, and thus die pretty quickly, they also absorb fire.Greens are your assassins, they love to jump onto the enemies and stab them for tons of damage. They aren't as tough as the browns, but they can take more beatings than blues or reds. They also absorb poison.Blues are your healers, they are terrible at fighting and die quickly, but they will resurrect any fallen minions.All in all the game has a lot of interesting creature designs, is pretty funny sometimes, and you can forge sweet new weapons and armor for your overlord.The only downsides is the minions have a tendency to get stuck in the scenery in one small part of the game.My playtime doesn't accurately reflect the time I've spent on this game as I own a physical copy not registered on Steam too.

												This is a combined review for the main game AND the Raising hell expansion pack.  Overlord is a great game where you basically play a parody version of Lord of the Rings, where you are an Overlord that looks a lot like Sauron and you have to use your minions, ie orcs/goblins or whatever to go and kill humans, halfflings, dwarves and elves.It's a very clever take on the genre, the humour and story added a great deal to the experience for me.  I wont spoil the story but having played the game through a second time I got all the little bits and pieces of hidden things going on, so it's more in depth than just running around and killing things.The expansion pack blends seemlessly with the game, if you have both DO INSTALL Raising Hell straight away, as you can do the missions from it in amongst the missions from the original game, I highly recommend that.The game mechanic of using your minions to attack your opponents, and pick up power ups etc works well, but sometimes their pathfinding is a bit average.  Overall, very funny and fun, only negatives are your minions not always obeying commands and some of the expansion levels use new mechanics that don't work well at all..(when you have to 'mow the grass' go online to get some hints, it will save you from smashing your computer).Don't let the negatives turn you away though.Original game 9/10Raising Hell 8/10

												Pikmin on crack is the simplest way to describe this title. And it mostly lives up to that name, albeit more about killing things than collecting stuff. ry 22, 2015
												Man, what to say about this game.I had never heard of it before I bought it. But seeing how it was only a dollar, and has very favorable reviews, I decided to take the plunge and blow my pocket change. Let me tell you, that was the best dollar I ever spent. This game is just amazing, addicting, and hilarious. It is a parody/satire of the traditional RPG genre, and at the same time somewhat of a RTS. Even though the graphics are a little dated, you won't notice once you start smashing villages and goons around with your gremlin army. In most ways it is just a normal RPG, while there is no "leveling", there are upgrades to make you more powerful for your armor and your minions, who will be doing mostly ALL of the fighting for you. Infact, your character is really just there to provide support, as the bulk of the combat is mainly just you micro managing your minions and making sure they dont suicide dive a group of goons. But with that being said, the minions are very well polished and dont often do stupid things unless you tell them too. I really am shocked at how well they are programmed, considering this game is almost 8 years old from the writing of this. It really does hold up very well, and as I am sitting here I can't think of one bad thing that bothered me over the course of me playing it. My favorite part though isn't the unique combat system, but the characters and the world in general. The game is just one big parody on almost every typical RPG ever made. This time around, you are the "anti" hero, whose sole goal is to be evil. But trust me, the only evil that is being done is too your gut, because I found myself laughing very often at the general silliness of the characters and the narration by Gnarl, your guide of all things evil, and the simpletons who guide your quests- erm sorry your "evil" conquests. The whole world is just tongue-in-cheek really, it is just a goofy atmosphere to be in and it is simply marvelous.There really isn't any reason not to buy this game, I can safely say that many people will not have had a previous experience like this before. I sure hadn't and I've been playing RPGs for a very long time and have played QUITE a bit of my fair share of them as well. Even if it's not on sale, I still urge you to take the $5 hit, which is still relatively cheap really for a game of such calliber. I really hate putting numbers on VG reviews, but in this case I will make a rare exception. For the sheer shock of finding such a quality game, and at the price I paid for it. There is only one score I see fit for it.10/10Evil always finds a way ;)

er 24, 2016
												Hail, Gluttonous Overlard!Overlord, the game where Pikmin meets English Fantasy Humor. Most games build up to you storming the evil Overlord's castle, slaying the wicked terror of the land and saving the day. Overlord starts after all that, with the Minions dragging your carcass out of the crypts, suiting you up and declaring you the new Overlord. Now its up to you to lead the armies of darkness to victory, to reconquer the land and restore your tower to its former glory. Today Spree... tomorrow the world!Mechanically the Overlord games are similar to Pikmin; you're leading a squad of minions, colour coded for your convenience, each with their own abilities and powers. Browns are your basic shock troops, dumb and with no special abilities other than hitting hard and having lots of health. Reds are ranged, Blues heal other minions and Greens are useless. I mean, Greens are for performing stealth attacks, though the number of times you can actually use that without them being slaughtered is fairly low. They're also used for various puzzles: Blues for example can dispell magic, reds cal move through fire barriers and browns... well browns just break things, but it doesn't have to be enemies.Unlike Pikmin however you're not totally useless - you are, after all, Not-Sauron and can get stuck in with your minions, joining in with battles to help deal damage. Its up to you if you're more the commander type who lets his minons do all the work or if you prefer to fight your own battles with the minions providing support. No Overlord worth his salt leaves home without suitably spiky armour, of course, so the game has a weapons and armour crafting mechanic where you can create new items to wield against the forces of good, imbued with the souls of your loyal minions to grant special abilities.Much like their master, minions can be upgraded by looting weapons and armour off of the fallen, making them more powerful and increasing their longevity. However, there are multiple enemies in the game that can and will simply obliterate minions no matter how upgraded they are, and it can be rather frustrating to see a full squad of fully upgraded minions reduced to jam by a falling boulder or a brand new enemy that has an untelegraphed instakill attack. Until Blues are introduced in the mid-late game there's no way to rez fallen minions, so you learn not to get attatched to them and that any upgrades are a temporary bonus rather than something to be reliably counted on, unless you want to be super conservative.The game controls are fairly simple, with having commands for "attack" and "return" along with "guard this point" and even a "sweep" mechanic where you control an entire pack of minions moving as an angry mob. The controls are designed with console in mind - the mouse controls for Sweep especially are fairly dire - so make sure to have a controller handy. However, they do the job fairly well, even if the Minions do have slightly suicidal tendencies and will happily run into fire or water if accidentally ordered. Dealing with the stupidity of your underlings is half the challenge, after all.The game's characters are for the most part charming and funny, especially your advisor Gnarl, who never fails to get a chuckle. The writers were clearly aiming for a Pratchett-esque sense of humor - Sir Terry's daughter was the head writer, after all - but it generally falls a little closer to Peter Molyneux's Fable for the most part. Occasionally rather funny, with a few slightly stretched out jokes.The game has a morality mechanic; you can choose to be good, helping the people of the land and winning their trust, or evil - quite "kick the dog" evil, in fact - which will make the first hate you, then fear you, then *obey* you. I do enjoy watching the transition between those stages, though if you want to be a good guy (Why did you buy a game called Overlord if you wanted to be the good guy?) you can. This kind of detracts from the game as well, though - rather than being Stalwart Heroes, many of your foes are in fact as unpleasant and evil as you are, and it was a bit of a disappointment that the game didn't let you be a proper marauding villain.There are downsides, of course; towards the middle of the game are a few truly painful levels that will leave you hoping they'd end, and it can be very difficult to farm souls for certain minions - blues in particular are rather difficult to get without resorting to cheese tactics. There will be several points where your minions The end of the game isn't quite as climactic as it could be and overall it could use a little polish, but if you're willing to look past that - and perhaps keep an FAQ handy - you've got an excellent experience waiting for you.Its worth noting that this game did in fact have a sequel: Overlord 2 tightened up the controls a lot and added a few new control mechanics, along with better spells. The Good/Evil morality system gave way to Dominate/Destroy, which i think suited the setting much better, the Level design was generally better, and the graphics and mechanics got an upgrade for the better. The plot was slightly improved, a new Mount mechanic was introduced and your Lair gets an upgrade to be something truly awesome. You can jump straight into Overlord 2, and its generally what i'd advise - but if you want the full experience give Overlord 1 a go and enjoy a good chuckle.Be warned, though; avoid the newer titles after that. They're very much cash-ins that miss the point of the original series...TLDR: The game has its problems, and lets face it, there are quite a few. Slightly frustrating controls and the occasional bad level design can spoil the experience a bit, but overall Overlord is something different and darkly humerous that i'd very much recommend!

												Hours of fun.  You play the villain out to conquer various heroes and the Overlord world.  You have four groups of minions at your disposal each with their own unique ability. Fantasy and dark comedy elements also had to the gameplay.  Great visual colors and a decent story that comes through at the end. Classic game.Final Thoughts:Overlord I is much harder than Overlord II, not sure why.  The minion AI isn't as good as II and sometimes the armored ones will dies because of camera difficulty or they will do something you do not want, which requires constant monitoring of minions during battle. er 21, 2016
												So, the funny thing about Overlord is that originally I never really finished it or saw a need to finish it. The premise is great: play the bad guy, kill the corrupted heroes. It's a pleasure to play overall, but trying to keep your minions alive is a pain and before long I lost my save file to an accidental hard drive failure. I just recently came back to play Overlord after playing Pikmin 2 again and was a little sad that I never really gave it another chance.It's inevitable that I'm going to compare this game to Pikmin so let's get that out of the way right now. This is evil fantasy Pikmin, just with a little more story, morality, and a ♥♥♥♥ton more strategy. You'll be gathering resources to spawn hundreds and hundreds of your four typed expendable minions, using their vast numbers to decimate the enemy, and get large treasures for yourself in a large fantasy world with many different "hubs". This is where the simularities end. Unlike Pikmin, Overlord is more forward with the fact that your minons are expendable and are going to die en masse. As you move through the areas, you'll find many opportunities to replenish your dwindling minion supply though you don't always get the choice to what minion types you can replenish. Typically the game will put out brown or red minon pits as to say "You're going to need tanks and ranged warriors up ahead" and that's as far as the hints go. From there the game throws everything at you when you least suspect it, decimates your well-equipped army, and forces you to fight your way back to the last pit with the knowledge of what to expect next time you make a run through that area. While losing a few minions isn't a big deal, losing a lot can be more painful, as minion survival and attack power is based on little items they collect as you break things and the spines of your enemies. Meaning a party wipe means that you'll need to grab more equipment or be disappointed in how squishy your new forces are against the incoming threat.I think my favorite part of Overlord however, is just how strategy oriented it is. While your minions are dumb, they're typically not dumb enough to outright kill themselves (typically) or attack things you don't want to attack (typically). Your job is to manage your horde in such a way to best succeed in every situation. I went for the straight in brown rush as browns are the toughest of your minions. But I could have used greens to flank enemies or clusters of reds to pick off enemies as they approached. You're given a lot of tools  to make the best of every situation you're put in no matter your strategy and it was something I truly enjoyed in this game.Last bit which may have been stronger at the time but more meh now, is the corruption mechanic. You can go balls to the wall evil and just destroy everything while taking things for yourself, or you can be pragmatic in your conquering and try to be nice to the locals in exchange for other benefits. Neither option is truly bad, though going 100% corrupt takes a lot of effort and is probably more trouble than it's worth. Each path will lead to different ultimate spells. A completely evil Overlord will get spells that scream "screw subtlety!" and promote a chaotic scorched earth playstyle, while a more reserved one will get spells that do a fair bit of damage but not accidentally harm your loyal worshipers in the process.Overall Overlord is a good game, and one I'm glad I gave a second chance in playing as ultimately I enjoyed it more than I did the Pikmin games. Sure those games are cute in their own way, but Overlord's gameplay is a complete improvement, feeling like a more advanced Pikmin (albiet more about fighting recklessly than managing your limited number of troops for long periods). I can easily recommend it for full price since the game's been out for a while and sells for peanuts, but I probably would have recommended it at full price if it wasn't anyways.
